bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J. F. Siler, November 5, 1947

div1.p: Hench informs Siler that he has accepted the invitation to speak on Walter Reed Memorial Day at the International Congress of Tropical Medicine. Hench discusses funding issues surrounding the memorialization of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J. F. Siler, November 5, 1947
div1.opener:
November 5, 1947
Colonel J. F. Siler
Secretary, Walter Reed Memorial
Association
3434 34th Place, N. W.
Washington 16, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
I have your lotter of October 30, mentioning the annual meeting
of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. First of all, let me thank you
most sincerely for your confidence in me, as a result of which you suggested
that I be a speaker on the “Walter Reed Memorial Day” of the International
Congress on Tropical Medicine. I have had some correspondence with Doctor
Sawyer and have accepted the invitation with pleasure.

I should like indeed to attend the meeting of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association this year but hesitate to ask you to change your date;
however, if you could hold the meeting Tuesday, November 25, I believe I
could be there. I have just returned from one trip and Mrs. Hench and I
are leaving November 13 to attend the inauguration of one of my oldest friends
as President of a college where I will represent my alma mater. This is in
Kentucky, then I am speaking in Charlottesville, Virginia on Monday, November 17
and am then going to New York where I have meetings and appointments the 18,
19, and 20. I will leave New York at midnight, Thursday, November 20, to
arrive in Washington, Friday morning, the 21st. I had intended renting a car
and going at once with Mrs. Hench to Mercersburg, where our son is in school.
He wanted us to arrive in the late afternoon. We had planned to drive to
Mercersburg, leaving Washington about 10:00 Friday morning, the 21st, perhaps
stopping at Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania for lunch as one of the main roads
goes right through Blue Ridge Summit. We thought to invite Blossom Reed to
have lunch with us and pay our respects to her and Mrs. Walter Reed and then
go on to Mercersburg, arriving their about 4:00 p.m., staying the weekend.
We would come back to Washington Monday morning November 24. I have appoint-
ments with two or three men in the Pentagon Building and want to see General
Reed about a matter. I would probably not arrive in Washington until almost
noon the 24th therefore it seems to me that the morning of the 25th would be
much more available for me. However, Colonel Siler, if this date is not con-
venient and if the Walter Reed Memorial Association meeting would not last too
long and if the date of Friday, November 21 is more agreeable, I can attend the
meeting that morning and leave for Mercersburg with Mrs. Hench after lunch.
If we are not able to stop to see Blossom and Mrs. Reed that day, we could stop
and see them on our return to Washington on the 24th. I must leave Washington
the late afternoon of the 25th in order to get home Wednesday night, the 26th
in time to have Thanksgiving with the children here. If neither the 21st nor
the 25 (the latter being preferable to me) is suitable, please do not go to
any bother to rearrange the date. I will simply have to be absent this year.
I don't have much to report.

One of my tentative appointments in New York is with an associate
of the Rockefellers to try to interest them in our little project with Camp
Lazear. I have been overwhelmed with medical work this year and have been
unable to do very little on the Camp Lazear project; however, the Cuban
Government has finally made Camp Lazear and our little shack a “national
monument” but that is merely a name, an honorary title as it were and so
far they have not set aside any money to preserve the place. That they
seem to be leaving up to us.

Mrs. Hench and I are planning our spring vacation to Florida and
Cuba. I hope to make the Cuban Government officials “fish or cut bait” and
by the spring meeting of the International Congress on Tropical Medicine I
hope to have some definite information regarding our project.
div1.closer: Sincerely, Philip S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
